stream_context.summary: Kaze imported Biobak’s finished Course 1 re-work, fixed rendering order and alpha issues, added a new infinite background and camera-based lens-flare, benchmarked performance, and began importing a batch of updated enemy/prop models in preparation for a one-stage public demo.

development_findings.summary: Course 1 visual re-work is complete and being integrated for an upcoming single-stage demo release.
development_findings.quote: Today we are working on the rework of Course 1 that Biobak just finished… so we can do the demo release.

development_findings.summary: Rendering-order and alpha-coverage bugs created artifacts; disabling coverage multiplication and re-sorting meshes fixed them and lowered RDP time slightly.
development_findings.quote: I just fixed one of the bugs… the RDP is slightly down. Cool.

development_findings.summary: Camera-dependent rotating lens-flare and ‘infinitely far’ sky layer implemented at Biobak’s request.
development_findings.quote: Instead of the whole level being nearby, there’s an infinitely far background here… you said you also wanted the sun to spin, correct?

development_findings.summary: New soft-body ‘nose jiggle’ physics for Mario implemented via a custom physics bone with minimal performance cost.
development_findings.quote: It is a genuine physics bone I added to Mario… this is hyper-optimized; if you make one change, it’s just going to crash.

development_findings.summary: Performance benchmarks show ~49–51 FPS on emulator and nearly 60 FPS on real N64; CPU spends ~73 % of frame idle after optimisations.
development_findings.quote: In a 33.3 ms frame, we have 24.3 ms idle time. That’s 73 % idle.

development_findings.summary: ROM size is 63 MB (close to the informal 64 MB ‘authentic’ limit); team wants to stay under that ceiling.
development_findings.quote: If you go over 64 MB, are you really still making an N64 game? It just feels like cheating to me.

development_findings.summary: Batch of updated actors (Yoshi Egg, Goomba King, Spiked Goomba, Bunny Goomba, Bouncy Flower, Windmill, Rabbits, Paragoomba, retro pipe/flag) imported or queued; changes reduce materials/bones and add new animations.
Future plan: series on Kaze’s second channel dissecting why each course is fun, hoping community feedback reveals design insights.
development_findings.quote: I was thinking of maybe making a series… I might realize important things; maybe people can give me important insights once they hear my thought processes.

context_findings.summary: Streaming is ‘minimum-effort’ side activity; YouTube/Patreon income is less than half his normal day-job salary.
context_findings.quote: Modding makes me some amount of money… but it’s not even half of what my normal job makes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze positions the project as pushing N64 hardware yet remaining authentic, taking pride in visual quality.
context_findings.quote: I’m pretty sure this already is the prettiest N64 game there is.

context_findings.summary: Considers branding himself as someone who ‘hates video games’ and therefore tries to make the first good one.
context_findings.quote: Do you think branding my content as like, I hate video games, which is why I’m trying to make a good one, would work out?

biobak.summary: Delivered full Course 1 geometry/texture overhaul and requested infinite background plus spinning sun effect.
Provided optimized replacements for multiple actors (e.g., Goomba King with three materials, trimmed polygons, updated Paragoomba, etc.).
Relies on Kaze to test on real N64; cannot predict hardware-specific issues.
biobak.quote: This Biobak is not modeling directly on the N64… he doesn’t know what’s going to break and what won’t.

badub.summary: Composed new multi-biome versions of Course 14 music and other tracks that can cross-fade in-game.
badub.quote: The song has versions for every biome… it will smoothly fade mini-channels in and out.

key_stories.title: The Course 1 Stripe Bug
key_stories.summary: After importing the new Course 1, a white stripe and layering errors appeared. Kaze traced the fault to alpha-coverage settings and mesh order, fixed them, and immediately verified a performance gain.
key_stories.challenge: Visual artifacts and performance drop after new geometry import.
key_stories.process: Investigated render layers, disabled ‘coverage in alpha’, re-sorted meshes, re-tested on console.
key_stories.outcome: Artifacts gone and RDP time lowered, restoring ~60 FPS on hardware.
key_stories.key_quote: We literally just imported the rework of the course… I just fixed one of the bugs and the RDP is slightly down.

key_stories.title: Mario’s Bouncy Nose
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted a small but delightful detail: Mario’s nose should bounce when he moves. He wrote a custom physics bone system that stores the previous frame’s nose position and applies pendulum equations each frame.
key_stories.challenge: Add soft-body behavior without heavy CPU cost.
key_stories.process: Created GeoMarioNoseJiggle bone, calculated acceleration, converted to yaw/pitch, applied hyper-optimized pendulum math.
key_stories.outcome: Cheap, stable nose jiggle that runs on real N64.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s a genuine physics bone… this is hyper-optimized; if you make one change, it’s just going to crash.

key_stories.title: Staying Under 64 MB
key_stories.summary: The ROM has reached 63 MB, nearing the 64 MB size at which many fans feel a game stops being ‘true’ N64. Kaze debated pushing past the limit but decided it would feel like cheating.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing new content with historical authenticity.
key_stories.process: Checked current ROM size, discussed technical upper limits and community expectations.
key_stories.outcome: Team intends to stay under 64 MB, treating it as a self-imposed boundary.
key_stories.key_quote: If you go over 64 MB, are you really still making an N64 game?
